text:
REPORT TYPE: Annual  
 REPORT TITLE: Annual Report for the Period Ending 27th August 2007 
 REPORT PERIOD: 28th August 2006 - 27th August 2007 
 AUTHOR: M Hill, J King 
 DATE OF REPORT: October 2007 
 MAP SHEETS: 1:250,000: Belele SF 50-11, 1:100,000: Meekatharra 2445  
 COMMODITY(s): Au 
 KEY WORDS: regolith mapping, literature review, open file research, quickbird data  
 Location: The Gidgee project consists of a single granted exploration licence 51/1044 
 located about 40 kilometres southwest of Meekatharra townsite in the Murchison 
 Mineral Field 
 Geology: The project covers recently recognised prospective rocks in the southern end 
 of the Abbotts greenstone belt, obscured by thick alluvium. 
 Work Done: Exploration undertaken during the period was focussed the compilation of 
 historical exploration data into an Access database, remote sensing dataset acquisition, 
 processing and regolith mapping.  
 Results: A detailed regolith map has been interpreted to increase the understanding in 
 the local area landscape evolution and potential controls of mineralisation dispersion 
 within the regolith profile. 
 Conclusions: The developed regolith-landform framework will assist with exploration 
 targeting within the tenements.

 bedrock in areas of cover is regarded as an inconclusive test of a targets’ potential.

text:
Exploration undertaken during the period was focussed the compilation of historical 
 exploration  data  into  an  Access  database,  remote  sensing  dataset  acquisition, 
 processing and regolith mapping (Figure 2). 
 Exploration through the variably thick transported regolith that accounts for 90% of 
 the project has hindered previous explorers.

12.text: Abbotts  greenstone  belt,  obscured  by  thick  alluvium.  Gold  mineralisation  exists  in

13.text: quartz  veins  within  granite  at  Wanganui  immediately  east  of  the  tenement  and  at

14.text: Weebacarry  south  of  the  tenement.  Previous  exploration  has  highlighted  two  5km

15.text: long linear zones of greater than 50ppb gold in aircore drilling at Marsh Bore and

16.text: Cement Well, both remain untested at depth (Figure 3).

text:
Abbotts  greenstone  belt,  obscured  by  thick  alluvium.  Gold  mineralisation  exists  in 
 quartz  veins  within  granite  at  Wanganui  immediately  east  of  the  tenement  and  at 
 Weebacarry  south  of  the  tenement.  Previous  exploration  has  highlighted  two  5km 
 long linear zones of greater than 50ppb gold in aircore drilling at Marsh Bore and 
 Cement Well, both remain untested at depth (Figure 3).

7.text: The area, previously interpreted to be entirely underlain by granite, has subsequently

8.text: been  interpreted  from  aeromagnetic  data  to  contain  greenstone  sequences  mostly

9.text: related  to  the  southern  part  of  the  Abbotts  greenstone  belt.  The  main  part  of  the

10.text: Abbotts belt is roughly triangular in shape extending over 40 kilometres north-south

Meekatharra townsite (Figure 3).  
 The area, previously interpreted to be entirely underlain by granite, has subsequently 
 been  interpreted  from  aeromagnetic  data  to  contain  greenstone  sequences  mostly 
 related  to  the  southern  part  of  the  Abbotts  greenstone  belt.  The  main  part  of  the 
 Abbotts belt is roughly triangular in shape extending over 40 kilometres north-south

12.text: E51/1044 the belt is essentially a canoe-shaped synform with the deepest part of the

13.text: keel  near  Big  Gum  Well  to  the  north  of  the  tenement  area.  In  the  better  exposed

14.text: western part of the belt a synclinal axis has been proved by facings in sediments and

17.text: The lowest stratigraphic units in the Abbotts belt are komatiitic and tholeiitic mafic

18.text: volcanics and pillow lavas with minor interflow sediments. These extrusive rocks pass

19.text: abruptly  upwards  into  a  distinct  coarse  volcanoclastic  unit  of  probable  dacitic

20.text: composition.  Textures  in  this  unit  suggest  they  are  reworked  volcanic  debris  flows

21.text: from a contemporaneous subaqueous volcanic eruption. The volcanics pass upwards

22.text: into a thick sequence of finer grained epiclastic volcanic rocks, sandstone and argillite

23.text: that occupy the core of the regional fold. Many horizons of sulphide-rich black shale

24.text: are present within the argillite units.

26.text: A  suite  of  ultramafic-mafic  sills  intrude  both  the  mafic  and  felsic  volcanic

27.text: stratigraphy.  Most  of  the  sills  are  differentiated  with  peridotitic  bases  passing  up

28.text: through  pyroxenite  to  gabbro.  In  the  upper  parts  of  the  stratigraphy  the  sills  are

29.text: commonly spatially associated with the sulphidic shale. The central and eastern parts

30.text: of  the  Abbotts  belt  are  extensively  weathered  and  outcrop  on  the  tenements  is

31.text: generally  poor.  In  this  area,  the  weathering  of  sulphidic  shale  produces  distinctive

32.text: dark gossans anomalous in base metals.

34.text: The Abbotts belt has a marked structural asymmetry about the north-south trending

35.text: synclinal  axis.  On  the  western  limb  the  stratigraphy  is  approximately  9  to  10

36.text: kilometres thick. On the eastern limb the stratigraphy has been flattened and is only 3

37.text: to  4  kilometres  thick.  A  major  northeast  trending  deformation  zone,  which  passes

38.text: through the length of E51/1044, generally marks the eastern contact of the greenstone

39.text: belt  with  an  external  granitoid.  The  zone  is  a  major  regional  feature  and  the

40.text: aeromagnetic  data  indicates  it  can  be  traced  to  the  southwest  for  at  least  100

41.text: kilometres. Several strike-parallel faults are also present within the stratigraphy some

42.text: of which may represent reactivated low angle normal faults.

text:
E51/1044 the belt is essentially a canoe-shaped synform with the deepest part of the 
 keel  near  Big  Gum  Well  to  the  north  of  the  tenement  area.  In  the  better  exposed 
 western part of the belt a synclinal axis has been proved by facings in sediments and 
 differentiated mafic sills. 
 The lowest stratigraphic units in the Abbotts belt are komatiitic and tholeiitic mafic 
 volcanics and pillow lavas with minor interflow sediments. These extrusive rocks pass 
 abruptly  upwards  into  a  distinct  coarse  volcanoclastic  unit  of  probable  dacitic 
 composition.  Textures  in  this  unit  suggest  they  are  reworked  volcanic  debris  flows 
 from a contemporaneous subaqueous volcanic eruption. The volcanics pass upwards 
 into a thick sequence of finer grained epiclastic volcanic rocks, sandstone and argillite 
 that occupy the core of the regional fold. Many horizons of sulphide-rich black shale 
 are present within the argillite units. 
 A  suite  of  ultramafic-mafic  sills  intrude  both  the  mafic  and  felsic  volcanic 
 stratigraphy.  Most  of  the  sills  are  differentiated  with  peridotitic  bases  passing  up 
 through  pyroxenite  to  gabbro.  In  the  upper  parts  of  the  stratigraphy  the  sills  are 
 commonly spatially associated with the sulphidic shale. The central and eastern parts 
 of  the  Abbotts  belt  are  extensively  weathered  and  outcrop  on  the  tenements  is 
 generally  poor.  In  this  area,  the  weathering  of  sulphidic  shale  produces  distinctive 
 dark gossans anomalous in base metals. 
 The Abbotts belt has a marked structural asymmetry about the north-south trending 
 synclinal  axis.  On  the  western  limb  the  stratigraphy  is  approximately  9  to  10 
 kilometres thick. On the eastern limb the stratigraphy has been flattened and is only 3 
 to  4  kilometres  thick.  A  major  northeast  trending  deformation  zone,  which  passes 
 through the length of E51/1044, generally marks the eastern contact of the greenstone 
 belt  with  an  external  granitoid.  The  zone  is  a  major  regional  feature  and  the 
 aeromagnetic  data  indicates  it  can  be  traced  to  the  southwest  for  at  least  100 
 kilometres. Several strike-parallel faults are also present within the stratigraphy some 
 of which may represent reactivated low angle normal faults. 
 5

4.text: occupying  the  central  part  of  the  syncline.  These  rocks  are  flanked  by  mafic  and

5.text: ultramafic  rocks,  the  contact  between  the  volcaniclatic  and  the  mafic-ultramafic

6.text: assemblage on the east side of the belt represented by the major northeast trending

7.text: structure referred to previously. Granitoid intrusions occur on the eastern side of the

8.text: syncline only and in the south have intruded the mafic-ultramafic assemblage.

10.text: There  are  no  known  old  workings  or  mineral  showings  within  E51/1044.  However

 assemblage on the east side of the belt represented by the major northeast trending

 syncline only and in the south have intruded the mafic-ultramafic assemblage. 
 There  are  no  known  old  workings  or  mineral  showings  within  E51/1044.  However

13.text: east of the eastern boundary of E51/1044.

19.text: Arcadia  project  area  of  which  229  holes  are  located  within  E51/1044.  Within

20.text: E51/1044 the holes were generally drilled at 200 metre intervals on lines 1600 metres

21.text: and  800  metres  apart.  Two  linear  gold  anomalies  (greater  than  50ppb  Au)  were

22.text: outlined (Figure 3): a southern anomaly extending from 2 Mile Bore to Marsh bore

23.text: (4.25 kilometres), probably the strike extension of gold mineralisation to the south at

24.text: Weebacarry  Bore,  and  a  northern  anomaly,  extending  northeast  from  Cement  Well

25.text: Tank for 5.5 kilometres. Highest values were 2 metres at 0.38 g/t Au from 76 metres

26.text: in ARCI147 in the northern anomaly and 2 metres at 310ppb Au from 80 metres in

27.text: ARCI193 in the southern anomaly. A more spurious group of isolated anomalous gold

28.text: values was intersected in the vicinity of Gidgee Bore with a best result of 2 metres at

29.text: 190ppb  Au  from  43  metres  in  a  possible  10  to  20  metre  wide  supergene  zone  in

30.text: ARCC4. In ARCC24 a 1 metre intersection of 1.36 g/t Au in alluvium from 34 metres

31.text: remains unexplained. The intersection occurs within a 10 metre wide zone of elevated

32.text: gold at the 5 to 100 ppb level and as such may be a supergene zone. However the lack

33.text: of elevated gold values in adjacent holes does not support this supposition. At Gidgee

34.text: Bore drill traverses located both margins of the greenstone belt. The western contact

35.text: with external granite was obscured by deep alluvium. The greenstone belt lithologies

36.text: consisted  of  metabasalt,  komatiitic  basalt,  mafic  schist  and  carbonaceous  and

37.text: sulphidic metasedimentary rocks. The sulphide present was predominantly pyrrhotite.

39.text: At Marsh Bore lithologies intersected included basalt, dolerite, ultramafic, granite and

40.text: gneiss.  Cover  conditions  varied  from  10  metres  to  108  metres,  with  deep  channel

41.text: clays  interested  in  several  holes.  A  thick,  hard  blanket  of  silcrete  was  encountered

42.text: near  surface  in  several  holes,  overlying  channel  clays.  Some  gold  anomalism  was

43.text: reported from this clearly non-residual material.

45.text: The  most  northern  traverses  at  Cement  Well  encountered  basalt  and  dolerite  with

46.text: minor quartz veining, and shallow oxidation. Transported alluvial cover was present

47.text: in all holes to depths of 4 to 10 metres. Little alteration was present, and no significant

48.text: cross¬cutting  mineralising  structures  were  intersected.  The  basalt  intersected  was

49.text: often schistose, and contained copper values of 10 to 250 ppb, but lacked gold and

50.text: arsenic anomalism, the only gold value of significance reported being 2 metres at 34

51.text: ppb from a foliated basalt in ARCI48.

text:
Cement Well (the convergence of mafic- ultramafic stratigraphy and the mineralised 
 Abernathy shear zone) (Figure 4). 
 Subsequently 348 aircore drill holes were completed for 21,014 metres drilled in the 
 Arcadia  project  area  of  which  229  holes  are  located  within  E51/1044.  Within 
 E51/1044 the holes were generally drilled at 200 metre intervals on lines 1600 metres 
 and  800  metres  apart.  Two  linear  gold  anomalies  (greater  than  50ppb  Au)  were 
 outlined (Figure 3): a southern anomaly extending from 2 Mile Bore to Marsh bore 
 (4.25 kilometres), probably the strike extension of gold mineralisation to the south at 
 Weebacarry  Bore,  and  a  northern  anomaly,  extending  northeast  from  Cement  Well 
 Tank for 5.5 kilometres. Highest values were 2 metres at 0.38 g/t Au from 76 metres 
 in ARCI147 in the northern anomaly and 2 metres at 310ppb Au from 80 metres in 
 ARCI193 in the southern anomaly. A more spurious group of isolated anomalous gold 
 values was intersected in the vicinity of Gidgee Bore with a best result of 2 metres at 
 190ppb  Au  from  43  metres  in  a  possible  10  to  20  metre  wide  supergene  zone  in 
 ARCC4. In ARCC24 a 1 metre intersection of 1.36 g/t Au in alluvium from 34 metres 
 remains unexplained. The intersection occurs within a 10 metre wide zone of elevated 
 gold at the 5 to 100 ppb level and as such may be a supergene zone. However the lack 
 of elevated gold values in adjacent holes does not support this supposition. At Gidgee 
 Bore drill traverses located both margins of the greenstone belt. The western contact 
 with external granite was obscured by deep alluvium. The greenstone belt lithologies 
 consisted  of  metabasalt,  komatiitic  basalt,  mafic  schist  and  carbonaceous  and 
 sulphidic metasedimentary rocks. The sulphide present was predominantly pyrrhotite. 
 At Marsh Bore lithologies intersected included basalt, dolerite, ultramafic, granite and 
 gneiss.  Cover  conditions  varied  from  10  metres  to  108  metres,  with  deep  channel 
 clays  interested  in  several  holes.  A  thick,  hard  blanket  of  silcrete  was  encountered 
 near  surface  in  several  holes,  overlying  channel  clays.  Some  gold  anomalism  was 
 reported from this clearly non-residual material. 
 The  most  northern  traverses  at  Cement  Well  encountered  basalt  and  dolerite  with 
 minor quartz veining, and shallow oxidation. Transported alluvial cover was present 
 in all holes to depths of 4 to 10 metres. Little alteration was present, and no significant 
 cross¬cutting  mineralising  structures  were  intersected.  The  basalt  intersected  was 
 often schistose, and contained copper values of 10 to 250 ppb, but lacked gold and 
 arsenic anomalism, the only gold value of significance reported being 2 metres at 34 
 ppb from a foliated basalt in ARCI48.

38.text: Ferruginous  and  leached  upper  saprolite  after  mafic  bedrock,  crops  out  in  the

39.text: northeast of the tenement. Granite crops on the north-eastern margin of the project.

40.text: Exploration  drilling  has  shown  the  greenstone  sequence,  known  as  the  Abbotts

41.text: Greenstone  Belt,  to  extend  further  south  than  previously  interpreted.  Beneath  the

42.text: cover  the  greenstone  is  commonly  deeply  weathered  displaying  a  variable  level  of

43.text: truncation.  Future  drilling  should  target,  at  a  minimum,  the  regional  redox  front,

44.text: especially where it is believed to be preserved.  Historical exploration has included

45.text: extensive base of hardpan or interface drilling as the primary reconnaissance method.

46.text: Such a method is fraught with difficulties, particularly where single element (Au only)

47.text: approaches are used, as is the case within the Gidgee project. The results can hardly

text:
Ferruginous  and  leached  upper  saprolite  after  mafic  bedrock,  crops  out  in  the 
 northeast of the tenement. Granite crops on the north-eastern margin of the project. 
 Exploration  drilling  has  shown  the  greenstone  sequence,  known  as  the  Abbotts 
 Greenstone  Belt,  to  extend  further  south  than  previously  interpreted.  Beneath  the 
 cover  the  greenstone  is  commonly  deeply  weathered  displaying  a  variable  level  of 
 truncation.  Future  drilling  should  target,  at  a  minimum,  the  regional  redox  front, 
 especially where it is believed to be preserved.  Historical exploration has included 
 extensive base of hardpan or interface drilling as the primary reconnaissance method. 
 Such a method is fraught with difficulties, particularly where single element (Au only) 
 approaches are used, as is the case within the Gidgee project. The results can hardly

11.text: Alchemy has searched the Wamex database and compiled the historical exploration

12.text: and drill hole database of the area which has given Alchemy a number of drill targets

13.text: (see Figure 4: Laterite Hill and Mustang Sally).

15.text: Alchemy has also acquired, compiled and reprocessed all the GIS datasets including

16.text: quickbird satellite imagery (Figures 5), landsat (Figure 6) and SRTM 90m (Figure 7).

19.text: Exploration through the variably thick transported regolith that accounts for 75% of

20.text: the project has hindered previous explorers. The widespread use of vacuum and auger

21.text: drilling  to  support  sampling  of  the  interface  between  transported  cover  and  the

22.text: bedrock in areas of cover is regarded as an inconclusive test of a targets’ potential.

24.text: A  detailed  regolith  map  has  been  interpreted  from  the  quickbird  and  landsat  TM

text:
Alchemy has searched the Wamex database and compiled the historical exploration 
 and drill hole database of the area which has given Alchemy a number of drill targets 
 (see Figure 4: Laterite Hill and Mustang Sally). 
 Alchemy has also acquired, compiled and reprocessed all the GIS datasets including 
 quickbird satellite imagery (Figures 5), landsat (Figure 6) and SRTM 90m (Figure 7). 
 Regolith Mapping and Interpretation 
 Exploration through the variably thick transported regolith that accounts for 75% of 
 the project has hindered previous explorers. The widespread use of vacuum and auger 
 drilling  to  support  sampling  of  the  interface  between  transported  cover  and  the 
 bedrock in areas of cover is regarded as an inconclusive test of a targets’ potential. 
 A  detailed  regolith  map  has  been  interpreted  from  the  quickbird  and  landsat  TM

28.text: Marsh Bore prospects to try and locate bedrock mineralisation.

30.text: The Gidgee Project predominantly comprises of a variably thick diluvial sedimentary

31.text: blanket  lying  over  a  variable  weathered  residuum  developed  in  the  underlying

32.text: bedrock, be it granite or greenstone. The south-flowing Hope River flows centrally

text:
Marsh Bore prospects to try and locate bedrock mineralisation.  
 The Gidgee Project predominantly comprises of a variably thick diluvial sedimentary 
 blanket  lying  over  a  variable  weathered  residuum  developed  in  the  underlying 
 bedrock, be it granite or greenstone. The south-flowing Hope River flows centrally

34.text: of  the  project  area.  Valley  calcrete  exists  predominantly  on  the  western  margin  of

35.text: Lake Annean and is likely to exist beneath veneers of younger cover within the lower

text:
of  the  project  area.  Valley  calcrete  exists  predominantly  on  the  western  margin  of 
 Lake Annean and is likely to exist beneath veneers of younger cover within the lower 
 reaches of the Hope River.
